titleStmt.title: A novel algorithm on adaptive backstepping control of fractional order systems

analytic.title: A novel algorithm on adaptive backstepping control of fractional order systems

biblStruct.note: Received date: 12 November 2014 Revised date: 21 January 2015 Accepted date: 5 March 2015 Preprint submitted to Neurocomputing

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This article presents a new method of designing the adaptive backstepping controller for triangular fractional order systems with non-commensurate orders. The fractional order indirect Lyapunov method is available for the 0 < α < 1 case, by introducing the appropriate transformations of frequency distributed model. Meanwhile, based on the semigroup property of fractional order derivative and the fractional order tracking differentiator, we extend the result to the 1 < α < 2 case. The case of controlling fractional order systems with unknown control input coefficient is also investigated. Simulation examples are given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed controllers.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Fractional order calculus can date back to the end of 17th century, the time when the classical integer order calculus was established. For three centuries, the fractional order calculus developed mainly as a pure theoretical mathematical field [1]. But over the last few decades, fractional order calculus has attracted increasing attention from control community. There are two major factors account for this. On one hand, many engineering plants and processes cannot be described concisely and precisely without the introduction of fractional order calculus [2,3]. On the other hand, it has been proved that fractional order controllers have more potential advantages and design freedom than integer order controllers [4,5]. Due to the great efforts devoted by researchers, a large volume of outcomes have been obtained on fractional order systems (FOSs). For the details of the most recent advance, one can refer to some excellent monographs i.e., [1,3,5], and the references therein as well.

Generally, it is not practical or even impossible to obtain the exact model of a controlled plant. As a result, analysis and synthesis of systems with model uncertainties has been one of the critical issues in the control field. There are mainly two types of methods of dealing with the uncertainties. The first one is the model-free method such as PI λ D µ control [6], CRONE (Commande Robuste d'Ordre Non Entier, meaning Non-integer-order Robust Control) control [7], fuzzy control [8] and ADRC (Active Disturbance Rejection Control) [9]. The second one is the model-based method such as state/output feedback robust control [10], SMC (Sliding Mode Control), H ∞ control [12] and adaptive control [13]. Similar to the conventional adaptive control, the fractional order adaptive control is also an effective model-based method to solve uncertain problems. In particular, the model reference adaptive control (MRAC) has been concerned by many scholars. Based on the fractional order tracking differentiator [14], Wei et al. extended the controlled plant of MRAC from the case of 0 < α < 1 to the case of 0 < α < 2 [15]. However, it is difficult to use the existing methods to control high order FOSs, especially for triangular FOSs, which are particular-yet wide-class of FOSs [16].

As a well-known control technique of stabilizing triangular nonlinear systems, by using the definition of a set of intermediate variables and the procedure of ensuring the negativity of Lyapunov functions that add up to build a common Lyapunov function for the overall system, the integer order backstepping technique has successfully been implemented in many fields [17]. Perhaps, adaptive backstepping may be a rare good solution to control uncertain FOSs in lower triangular form. Some scholars have spearheaded the study on fractional order backstepping technique [18,19], but only a small particular class of systems have been studied and uncertainties have not been taken into account. Reference [20] firstly proposed the fractional order adaptive backstepping control approach, and a similar stability analysis method as that of [18,19] was adopted.

Although the tools and approaches of FOSs and adaptive backstepping control are not new, implementation of adaptive backstepping control for fractional order system dynamics is new. The reason is the definition of derivative that is generalized by Leibniz rule. The rule, which also generalizes the integer order case [21], yields infinitely many terms for the product, and it becomes difficult to figure out stability by choosing a square type Lyapunov function and obtaining its time derivative. So far, there are mainly two class of Lyapunov functions to be used: the direct Lyapunov method [22][23][24][25] and the indirect Lyapunov method [26][27][28][29]. we use the latter one in our study, mainly because of the following two points. The latter one not only can be applied to the non-commensurate case, but also has great relevance with the widely-used numerical simulation algorithm (short memory principle or Oustaloup recursive algorithm).

Motivated by the aforementioned reasons, this article aims at developing a fractional order adaptive backstepping control (FOABC) algorithm to solve the tracking problem of FOS in lower triangular form. A novel class of Lyapunov functions are constructed by the aid of the frequency distributed model. The limitation of conversational square type Lyapunov function is overcome, based on these Lyapunov functions. To obtain the required fractional order derivative signals in time from some given signal and extend the results from the 0 < α < 1 case to the 1 < α < 2 case, our new outcome 'fractional order tracking differentiator' [14] is introduced. It is also shown that the novel FOABC can be implemented effectively with the help of commercially available software.

The remainder of this article is structured as follows. Section 2 briefly presents the control objective of this study and some necessary concepts and lemmas. FOABC algorithm is proposed in Section 3, based on the frequency distributed model and the indirect Lyapunov method. In Section 4, some numerical simulations are provided to illustrate the validity of the proposed algorithm. Finally, Section 5 concludes this study.

div.head: Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider the following fractional order system
where the fractional non-commensurate order α i belong to (0, 2) for i ∈ N
and u ∈ R are the system state and the control input. d i , i ∈ N are known nonzero real constants, the vector
div.formula: θ ∈ R m , m ∈ N is constant and unknown, ψ i (•) ∈ R, ϕ i (•) ∈ R m , i ∈ N are known nonlinear functions and b is the input coefficient.
div.p: It can be seen that the linearized system matrix of Eq.( 1) has a lower triangular form, and thus system Eq.( 1) is referred as the lower triangular system. In this study, the control object is to force the output y to asymptotically track the reference signal r with the following assumptions. Assumption 2. The reference signal r and its first j i=1 α i -th order derivatives are piecewise continuous and bounded, j ∈ N.

Before deriving the main results, we need the following useful definition and lemmas. Fractional order calculus is the generalization concept of the conventional integer order calculus. There are three main commonly used definitions for D α : Grünwald-Letnikov definition, Riemann-Liouville definition and Caputo's definition. Considering its wellunderstood physical sense and wide application in engineering, the following Caputo's derivative is adopted in this study
div.formula: c D α t f (t) = 1 Γ (m -α) t c f (m) (τ) (t -τ) α-m+1 dτ,(2)
div.p: where
div.formula: m -1 ≤ α < m, m ∈ N, Γ (α) = ∞ 0 x α-1 e -x
div.p: dx is the Gamma function. It follows from the Caputo's definition that for arbitrary 0 < p, q < 1, the additive law of exponents (semigroup property) holds with zero initial conditions
div.formula: c D p t c D q t f (t) = c D q t c D p t f (t) = c D p+q t f (t) .(3)
div.p: To simplify the notation, the fractional derivative of order α with the lower terminal at 0 can be denoted as D α instead of 0 D α t .
Lemma 1.
[14] Suppose v(t) is the input signal to be differentiated with |D α v (t)| < ∞ and r 1 is the allowed maximum of control input u(t), then the solution of the following tracking differentiator
div.formula: D α x 1 (t) = x 2 (t) , D α x 2 (t) = u (t)(4)
div.p: is convergent in the sense of that: x 1 (t) is uniformly convergent to v(t) on [0, ∞) as r → ∞, and x 2 (t) is the general α-th order differentiation of v(t), where the control input u
div.formula: (t) = -r 1 tanh x 1 (t) -v (t) + x 2 (t)|x 2 (t)| r 1 1 -Γ 2 (α+1) Γ(2α+1) , r 2 , r 2 > 0 and tanh (z, γ) = e γz -e -γz
div.p: e γz +e -γz .
Remark 1. The function tanh (•) is introduced to replace the sign function sgn (•) in the conventional tracking differentiator [7], which can suppress the chattering phenomenon.
Lemma 2.
[27] The fractional order system D α y (t) = u (t) with 0 < α < 1, y (t) ∈ R and u (t) ∈ R, can be regarded as the following linear continuous frequency distributed model
div.formula: ∂z(ω,t) ∂t = -ωz (ω, t) + u (t) , y (t) = ∞ 0 µ α (ω) z (ω, t) dω,(5)
div.p: where µ α (ω) = sin(απ) πω α and z (ω, t) ∈ R.

Remark 2. The definition of the initial conditions of fractional differential systems is an old problem which has not received satisfactory solutions. Neither Riemann-Liouville nor Caputo's definitions for fractional differentiation can be used to take into account initial conditions in a convenient way from a physical point of view [30]. Owing to the frequency distributed model, and particularly with these true state variables, many applications can be considered, as observers, state space controllers, and stability analysis by Lyapunov technique [31].

div.head: Model transformation
div.p: By introducing the transformation
with δ 1 = 1, δ j = j-1 i=1 d i , j = 2, • • • , n, then the system in Eq.( 1) can be converted into the following system

which is called as the normalized fractional order chain system. Consequently, the following section aims at finding the appropriate control input u, which can guarantee the asymptotic tracking of the output y to the reference signal r.

Remark 3. Based on the appropriate transformations of coordinates, the general lower triangular FOS Eq.( 1) can be converted into the normalized fractional order chain system Eq.( 7). If the coefficients d i = 1, i ∈ N -{n}, the system Eq.( 1) reduces to the normalized fractional order chain system directly.

div.head: FOABC with known b
div.p: Theorem 1. Consider plant Eq.( 1) with order 0 < α i < 1, i ∈ N and the known b. Let the following designs be adopted for the system: the error variables
the stabilizing functions
div.formula: τ 1 = -c 1 ε 1 -ψ1 -φT 1 θ, c 1 > 0, τ i = -c i ε i -ε i-1 -ψi -φT i θ + D α i τ i-1 , c i > 0, i = 2, • • • , n -1,(9)
div.p: the parameter update law θ = Λ n j=1 φ j ε j , Λ > 0, (10) the adaptive control law
div.formula: u = 1 b (-c n ε n -ε n-1 -ψn -φT n θ + D n j=1 α j r + D α n τ n-1 ), c n > 0,(11)
div.p: Then all the signals in the closed-loop adaptive system are globally uniformly bounded, and the asymptotic tracking is achieved as
Proof: The design procedure is elaborated in the following. The differential equation of error variables can be expressed as
div.formula:                        D α 1 ε 1 = ε 2 + τ 1 + ψ1 + φT 1 θ, D α 2 ε 2 = ε 3 + τ 2 + ψ2 + φT 2 θ -D α 2 τ 1 , . . . D α n-1 ε n-1 = ε n + τ n-1 + ψn-1 + φT n-1 θ -D α n-1 τ n-2 , D α n ε n = bu + ψn + φT n θ -D n j=1 α j r -D α n τ n-1 .(13)
div.p: Step 1. We start with the first differential equation of Eq.( 13) by considering τ 1 as virtual control variable. By using Lemma 2, it follows from the frequency distributed model that
div.formula: ) with µ α 1 (ω) = ω -α 1 sin (α 1 π)/π.
div.p: Since θ is unknown, the task in this step is fulfilled with an adaptive controller consisting of a control law and an update law to achieve the tracking task y → r with respect to the Lyapunov function
where θ = θθ is the parameter estimate error and Λ is a positive definite matrix.
Then the derivative of V 1 is given by
div.formula: V1 = ∞ 0 µ α 1 (ω) z 1 (ω, t) ∂z 1 (ω,t) ∂t dω -θT Λ -1 θ = - ∞ 0 ωµ α 1 (ω) z 2 1 (ω, t) dω + ε 1 (ε 2 + ψ 1 + φT 1 θ + τ 1 ) -θT (Λ -1 θ -φ1 ε 1 ). (16
div.p: Selecting an appropriate stabilizing function τ 1 as Eq.( 9), then the resulting derivative is
Clearly, if ε 2 = 0 and θ = Λ φ1 ε 1 , then ε 1 are both guaranteed to converge to zero asymptotically.
Step 2. Study the second equation of Eq.( 13) by considering τ 2 as virtual control variable, then the related frequency distributed model is
div.formula: ∂z 2 (ω,t) ∂t = -ωz 2 (ω, t) + ε 3 + τ 2 + ψ2 + φT 2 θ -D α 2 τ 1 , ε 2 = ∞ 0 µ α 2 (ω) z 2 (ω, t) dω, (18
) with µ α 2 (ω) = ω -α 2 sin (α 2 π)/π.
div.p: The control objective is to make ε 2 → 0 as t → ∞. Define a control Lyapunov function as
and its time derivative is given by
div.formula: V2 = V1 + ∞ 0 µ α 2 (ω) z 2 (ω, t) ∂z 2 (ω,t) ∂t dω = -2 j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω -c 1 ε 2 1 -θT (Λ -1 θ -φ1 ε 1 ) +ε 2 (ε 1 + ε 3 + τ 2 + ψ2 + φT 2 θ -D α 2 τ 1 ). (20
div.p: Design the stabilizing function τ 2 as Eq.( 9), then the resulting derivative of
div.formula: V 2 is V2 = -2 j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω + ε 2 ε 3 -2 j=1 c j ε 2 j -θT (Λ -1 θ -2 j=1 φ j ε j ).(21)
div.p: Similar to Step 1, if ε 3 = 0 and θ = Λ 2 j=1 φ j ε j , then ε 2 is guaranteed to converge to zero asymptotically. In Step 1, the parameter update law Λ 2 j=1 φ j ε j reduces to Λ φ1 ε 1 while ε 2 = 0.
Step i(i = 3, • • • , n-1). Study the ith equation of Eq.( 13) with the virtual control variable τ i . Then the related frequency distributed model is
div.formula: ∂z i (ω,t) ∂t = -ωz i (ω, t) + ε i+1 + τ i + ψi + ϕ T i θ -D α i τ i-1 , ε i = ∞ 0 µ α i (ω) z i (ω, t) dω, (22
) with µ α i (ω) = ω -α i sin (α i π)/π.
div.p: The control objective is to stabilize the (ε 1 , ε 2 )-system Eqs.( 18) and ( 22). The control Lyapunov function is chosen as
div.formula: V i = V i-1 + 1 2 ∞ 0 µ α i (ω) z 2 i (ω, t) dω. (23
div.p: Its time derivative is given by
div.formula: Vi = Vi-1 + ∞ 0 µ α i (ω) z i (ω, t) ∂z i (ω,t) ∂t dω = -i j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω -i-1 j=1 c j ε 2 j -θT (Λ -1 θ -i-1 j=1 φ j ε j ) +ε i (ε i-1 + τ i + ψi + φT i θ -D α i τ i-1 ) + ε i ε i+1 . (24
div.p: Design the stabilizing function τ i as Eq.( 9), then the resulting derivative of
div.formula: V i is Vi = -i j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω + ε i ε i+1 -i j=1 c j ε 2 j -θT (Λ -1 θ -i j=1 φ j ε j ).(25)
div.p: Indeed, when ε i+1 = 0 and θ = Λ 2 j=1 φ j ε j , then ε i is guaranteed to converge to zero asymptotically.
Step n. In the last step n, the actual control input u appears and is at our disposal. The dynamics of ε n can be derived by the last equation of Eq.( 13), whose frequency distributed model is
div.formula: ∂z n (ω,t) ∂t = -ωz n (ω, t) + bu + ψn + φT n θ -D n j=1 α j r -D α n τ n-1 , ε n = ∞ 0 µ α n (ω) z n (ω, t) dω, (26) with µ α n (ω) = ω -α n sin (α n π)/π.
div.p: The aim is to make ε n → 0 as t → ∞. Select the Lyapunov function as
div.formula: V n = V n-1 + 1 2 ∞ 0 µ α n (ω) z 2 n (ω, t) dω, (27
div.p: then one can obtain its time derivative as
div.formula: Vn = Vn-1 + ∞ 0 µ α n (ω) z n (ω, t) ∂z n (ω,t) ∂t dω = -n j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω -n-1 j=1 c j ε 2 j -θT (Λ -1 θ -n-1 j=1 φ j ε j ) +ε n (ε n-1 + bu + ψn + φT n θ -D n j=1 α j r -D α n τ n-1 ). (28
div.p: Design the stabilizing function u as Eq.( 11) and θ as Eq.( 10), then the resulting derivative of
div.formula: V n is Vn = - n j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω + c j ε 2 j (29)
div.p: Consequently, ε n is guaranteed to converge to zero asymptotically. This completes the proof.

div.head: FOABC with unknown b
div.p: Theorem 2. Consider plant Eq.( 1) with order 0 < α i < 1, i ∈ N and the known of sgn( b). Let the following designs be adopted for the system: the error variables
the stabilizing functions
div.formula: τ 1 = -c 1 ε 1 -ψ1 -φT 1 θ, c 1 > 0, τ i = -c i ε i -ε i-1 -ψi -φT i θ + D α i τ i-1 , c i > 0, i = 2, • • • , n -1,(31)
div.p: the parameter update law
div.formula:      θ = Λ n j=1 φ j ε j , Λ > 0, ˙p = -γsgn( b)ε n v, γ > 0, (32
div.p: the adaptive control law
div.formula: u = pv, v = -c n ε n -ε n-1 -ψn -φT n θ + D n j=1 α j r + D α n τ n-1 , c n > 0, (33
div.p: Then all the signals in the closed-loop adaptive system are global uniformly bounded, and the asymptotic tracking is achieved as

Proof: Because the first n -1 step are the same as those in Theorem 1, we begin with step n. The last equation of Eq.( 13) has frequency distributed model as Eq.( 26). The goal of this step is to make ε n → 0 as t → ∞. Consider only the sign of b is known, we define p as an estimate of p = 1/ b and p = pp as the parameter estimate error. Then the following equation holds
div.formula: ) Note that bu = b pv = v -b pv. (36
div.p: Select the Lyapunov function as
div.formula: V n = V n-1 + 1 2 ∞ 0 µ α n (ω) z 2 n (ω, t) dω + b 2γ p2 ,(37)
div.p: thus one can deduce that
div.formula: Vn = Vn-1 + ∞ 0 µ α n (ω) z i (ω, t) ∂z n (ω,t) ∂t dω - | b| γ p ˙p = -n j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω -n-1 j=1 c j ε 2 j -θT (Λ -1 θ -n j=1 φ j ε j ) +ε n (ε n-1 + v + ψn + φT n θ -D n j=1 α j r -D α n τ n-1 ) - | b| γ p[γsgn (b) ε n v -˙p].(38)
div.p: Design the actual control u and virtual control v as Eq.( 33), θ and ˙p as Eq.( 32), then the resulting derivative of
div.formula: V n is Vn = - n j=1 ∞ 0 ωµ α j (ω) z 2 j (ω, t) dω + c j ε 2 j .(39)
div.p: Thereafter, ε n is guaranteed to converge to zero asymptotically, which establishes Theorem 2.

Remark 4. The controllers designed in Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 achieve the goals of stabilization and tracking. The proof of these theorems is a direct consequence of the recursive procedure, because a Lyapunov function is constructed for the entire system including the estimated parameters . The number of estimated parameter is equal to the number of unknown parameters.

Remark 5. Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 propose an adaptive fractional order backstepping algorithm for two kinds of fractional order systems in triangular form, respectively. If α i = α, i ∈ N those Theorem reduce to the commensurate case. In addition, if α = 1, the corresponding result is integer order case. If r = 0, the tracking problem becomes a stabilization problem.

3.4. FOABC with the system order in (1, 2) Theorem 3. Consider plant Eq.( 1) with order 0 < α i < 1, i ∈ N -{n}, 1 < α n < 2 and the known b. Let the following designs be adopted for the system: the error variables
div.formula:                  ε 1 = x1 -r, ε i = xi -D i-1 j=1 α j r -τ i-1 , i = 2, • • • , n -1, ε n1 = xn -D n-1 j=1 α j r -τ n-1 , ε n2 = D α n1 xn -D n-1 j=1 α j +α n1 r -τ n , 0 < α n1 , α n2 < 1, α n1 + α n2 = α n ,(40)
div.p: the stabilizing functions
div.formula:          τ 1 = -c 1 ε 1 -ψ1 -φT 1 θ, c 1 > 0, τ i = -c i ε i -ε i-1 -ψi -φT i θ + D α i τ i-1 , c i > 0, i = 2, • • • , n -1, τ n = -c n1 ε n1 -ε n-1 + D α n1 τ n-1 , c n1 > 0, (41) the parameter update law θ = Λ n j=1 φ j ε j + Λ φn ε n2 , Λ > 0,(42)

div.head: Illustrative Examples
div.p: Numerical examples illustrated in this section are implemented via the piecewise numerical approximation algorithm. More information about the algorithm can refer to [32].
Consider the system as follows:

where the control input coefficient b = 3 and the parameter θ = 0.1 is viewed as unknown constant. The initial state x(0) = [ 0.3 -0.4 0.2 ] T . The reference signal is chosen as r(t) = sin(t). The parameters of the fractional order tracking differentiator is selected as r 1 = 50, r 2 = 1. The total simulation time is set as 10s. To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed approaches in Theorem 1 -Theorem 4, numerical simulation will be carried out on four examples, respectively.

Example 1. Consider the system in Eq.( 51) with α = 0.7 and the known b. To verify the effectiveness of our algorithm in noisy environments, a white noise w(t), S NR = w(t) 2 y(t) 2 = 5% is added to output terminal. Select the controller parameters c 1 = c 2 = c 3 = 5 and Λ = 1, the initial parameter estimate θ(0) = 0, then one obtains the tracking performance of the system shown in Fig. 1. It is seen that in such noisy environments, the reference signal r(t) is followed very precisely by y(t) and the tracking error ε converges to a smaller range rapidly. In addition, ε does not stop at 0 but has a tiny fluctuations near 0. There are three main reasons leading to this result. Firstly, the required fractional order derivative signal of given signals, such as r(t) and τ i , i = 1, 2, • • • , n -1, is difficult to obtain. To a certain extent, FOTD is available to deal with it. However, there also exist time delays and deviations. Secondly, the measurement output signal is mixed with the white noisy w(t). Due to the existence of the measurement noise, the exacter derivative value FOTD obtains, the bigger steady error the close-loop system produces. Thirdly, errors will be introduced in the process of numerical calculation itself. For quantitative comparison, the L 2 norm of tracking error ε 1 (t) and control input u(t) are calculated as follows, respectively ε 1 (t) 2 = 131.7015, u (t) 2 = 171.0229.

Example 2. Consider the system in Eq.( 51) with α = 0.7, the unknown b and white noise w(t) in the case of S NR = w(t) 2 y(t) 2 = 5%. The simulation has been carried out using the same parameters as in Example 1 except γ = 5 and p(0) = 0. Fig. 2 is plotted the tracking performance of the closed-loop control system. The results obtained show that tracking is well achieved by the proposed FOABC with an acceptable transient performance. Moreover, the L 2 norm of ε 1 (t) and u(t) in this example are also calculated as follows, respectively ε 1 (t) 2 = 133.7486, u (t) 2 = 934.5088.
As can be observed, under the same simulation conditions, to obtain the comparable tracking accuracy, the case of unknown b needs greater control cost.

Example 3. Consider the system in Eq.( 51) with α = 1.2 and the known b. Using the design methods in Theorem 3, the FOABC can be constructed. The relevant simulation is performed with the controller parameters c 1 = c 2 = c 31 = c 32 = 5, Λ = 1, the initial estimate of unknown parameter θ(0) = 0 and the new system order α 31 = 0.5. Fig. 3 shows the output response and the tracking error of the closed-loop control system, while Fig. 4 shows the needed control input.

The results clearly demonstrate the asymptotic tracking of the closed-loop control system. Similar to the preceding examples, in this example, the L 2 norm of ε 1 (t) and u(t) are calculated as follows, respectively shown in Fig. 6. It is verified that the FOABC is feasible for such fractional order systems with the order 1 < α i < 2 and the unknown b.
In addition, the L 2 norm of ε 1 (t) and u(t) of this case are calculated, respectively ε 1 (t) 2 = 4.7317, u (t) 2 = 178.254.

It is easy to show that when the measurement noise with S NR = 5% is removed, no matter the coefficient b is known or unknown, under the same controller conditions, the tracking accuracy improves; when the coefficient b changes from known to unknown, with the comparable control cost, the tracking performance gets worse. However, there is no denying that the proposed controller design methods are effectiveness.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this article, the FOABC algorithm has been proposed. With this algorithm, an effective adaptive controller can be designed for fractional order systems with order 0 < α < 2 in both known and unknown cases of the input coefficient. The design procedure is constructed in such a way that the controllers can always be constructed with appropriate choices of some design parameters. It is believed that the approaches provide a new avenue to solve such problem. There are many promising directions for future research: i) Consider the bounded time-varying disturbance or unmodelled dynamics. ii) Study the mutiple-input mutiple-output case instead of the SISO case. iii) Extend the results from state feedback case to the output feedback case. iv) Study the controller design problem with the desired transient dynamic.

By applying the fractional order tracking differentiator in Lemma 2, one can get D α n1 x n from the measured signal x n . Afterward, the subsequent proof can be completed as Theorem 1, thus it is omitted here. Theorem 4. Consider plant Eq.( 1) with order 0 < α i < 1, i ∈ N -{n}, 1 < α n < 2 and the known of sgn( b). Remark 6. Since extending Theorem 3 to Theorem 4 is very similar to that from Theorem 1 to Theorem 2, the proof of Theorem 4 has been omitted.

div.head: Remark 7.
div.p: As is known, (0, 1) and (1, 2) are two feasible intervals of the system fractional order. The case of (0, 1) is studied in Theorem 1 and Theorem 2. In fact, any one of α i can belong to (1, 2), Without loss of generality, Theorem 3 and Theorem 4 study the case of 1 < α n < 2.

Remark 8. In this study, the signal D α i τ i , i ∈ N -{n}, and D i j=1 α j r, i ∈ N, can be obtained from fractional order tracking differentiator. In fact, any efficient real-time methods which can get the expected derivative of τ i or r can be used here.
